description: Names the law as the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023, states it applies across India (with any specified exceptions), and notes when it comes into force.
examples: A police officer cites BNS 2023 in a charge, confirming the law’s name and applicability.
A case filed after July 1, 2024 proceeds under BNS because it has commenced.

description: Provides key definitions used throughout the Act, such as terms for documents, property, injury, valuable security, and other concepts needed to interpret offences.
examples: In a forgery case, the meaning of 'document' is taken from Section 2.
A theft case turns on whether an item qualifies as 'property' under the definitions.

description: Explains how words and phrases should be read in context across the Act, and clarifies general interpretive rules.
examples: A court uses general explanations to interpret gendered terms as inclusive where specified.
Ambiguous wording in an offence clause is clarified using this section’s interpretive rules.

section_title: Punishment of offences committed within India
description: Anyone committing an offence within India is liable to be punished under this law, regardless of nationality, unless an exception applies.
examples: A foreign tourist committing fraud in Delhi is prosecuted under BNS.
A resident of India committing assault in Mumbai is charged under BNS.

description: Certain offences committed outside India can still be tried in India when the law gives jurisdiction, such as offences by Indian citizens abroad or on Indian-registered ships/aircraft.
examples: An Indian citizen commits cyber fraud while abroad; they can be tried in India.
An offence on an Indian-registered vessel on the high seas is triable in India.

section_title: Act not to affect special or local laws
description: Where a special or local law provides differently, that law can prevail over the general provisions of this Act.
examples: A special anti-terror law procedure overrides general BNS procedure for that case.
A state-specific law on a narrow subject governs instead of the general rule here.

description: When a company commits an offence, persons in charge and responsible for its conduct may be deemed guilty, subject to defences like lack of knowledge or due diligence.
examples: A firm’s manager is prosecuted with the company for environmental violations.
A director shows due diligence to avoid liability for the company’s fraud.

section_title: Act done by several persons in furtherance of common intention
description: When multiple people share a common intention and act together, each is responsible for the act as if they did it alone.
examples: Two people plan and jointly assault someone; both are liable for the assault.
A group distracts a shopkeeper while one steals; all share liability.

description: Clarifies when an act is considered voluntary and when consent is valid or invalid for the purpose of offences.
examples: Consent obtained by threat is invalid for sexual or bodily offences.
A person acting without free will due to intoxication may negate 'consent'.

description: Good faith actions, done with due care and attention, can provide protection in certain contexts defined by the Act.
examples: A doctor administers treatment in an emergency with due care; this may be protected.
A citizen restrains a thief believing it lawful and with care; good faith applies.

description: States that words importing the masculine include the feminine and vice versa, and singular includes plural, unless the context shows otherwise.
examples: A provision using 'he' applies equally to 'she' or 'they' where intended.
A rule mentioning 'document' can also cover multiple documents.

description: Defines and explains who counts as a 'public servant' for offences involving public duty or corruption.
examples: A municipal engineer is treated as a public servant in a bribery case.
An officer in a public-sector company is covered for misuse of office.

description: Clarifies what counts as movable property for offences like theft, mischief, and criminal breach of trust.
examples: A laptop and phone are movable property for theft.
Goods in transit qualify as movable property for misappropriation.

description: Defines acting 'dishonestly' as doing something with the intention of causing wrongful gain or wrongful loss.
examples: Selling someone else’s bike as your own to profit is dishonest.
Hiding a found wallet to keep the cash causes wrongful loss to the owner.

description: Defines 'fraudulently' as doing an act with intent to defraud—deceiving someone to their prejudice.
examples: Creating a fake invoice to obtain payment is fraudulent.
Using a forged signature to get a loan is done fraudulently.

description: A person has 'reason to believe' something when there are sufficient grounds to think it is true, not just suspicion.
examples: A jeweler buying gold at far below market price has reason to believe it’s stolen.
An email from a bank domain looks genuine—without red flags, no reason to believe it’s fake.

description: Explains when something is considered counterfeit, such as making an imitation to deceive.
examples: Producing fake currency notes qualifies as counterfeiting.
Copying a brand hologram to pass off goods as genuine is counterfeit.

description: Defines 'document' broadly to include any matter expressed or described upon any substance by letters, figures, or marks intended to be used as evidence.
examples: A printed contract and a PDF agreement are documents.
A digital certificate stored in a phone wallet is a document.

description: Describes instruments that create or acknowledge a legal right, liability, or obligation, making them valuable security.
examples: A signed promissory note is a valuable security.
A share certificate that establishes ownership is a valuable security.

description: Defines 'offence' as any act or omission punishable under the BNS or any law in force.
examples: Failure to act when the law requires it can be an offence.
Assault as defined in BNS is an offence.

description: Explains what it means to 'harbour' a person—providing shelter, assistance, or concealment to help them evade arrest or detection.
examples: Giving a fugitive a room and hiding them from police is harbouring.
Supplying food and money to help a wanted person escape is harbouring.

description: States that the word 'act' includes both actions and illegal omissions where the law imposes a duty.
examples: Leaving a dangerous animal unrestrained in breach of duty is an 'act' here.
A parent failing to provide necessary care when legally bound is an omission.

description: An act is done voluntarily when it proceeds from the will, with knowledge of likely effects, rather than by accident.
examples: Throwing a stone at a window and breaking it is voluntary.
Accidentally brushing someone while walking is not voluntary assault.

description: Defines the use of force against a person and when force is considered applied.
examples: Pushing someone in a crowd is applying force.
Grabbing a person’s arm to restrain them involves force.

description: Defines 'injury' as any harm illegally caused to body, mind, reputation, or property.
examples: Punching someone causes bodily injury.
Publishing a false statement that harms reputation is an injury.

description: Clarifies references to 'life' include the life of a human being after birth.
examples: Homicide provisions apply only after a child is born alive.
Feticide is addressed under specific provisions, not general homicide.

description: Explains the meaning of 'death' as the death of a human being.
examples: Homicide charges require proof a person has died.
Causing death by negligence uses this definition of death.

description: Refines what counts as good faith, emphasizing due care and attention in actions.
examples: A pharmacist dispenses medicine per prescription, showing due care.
A rescuer breaks a car window to save a child with reasonable care.

description: Distinguishes special or local laws from general law for conflict and interpretation.
examples: A municipal bye-law is a local law overriding general provisions for that municipality.
A securities statute is a special law for market offences.

description: Defines what is considered a public place for offences that depend on location or public access.
examples: A railway platform is a public place.
A privately owned mall’s common areas open to the public are public places.

description: Explains how to calculate fractions of imprisonment or fines where needed.
examples: A sentence of 1.5 years is computed as 18 months.
A proportionate fine is calculated per this rule.

description: Defines abetment as instigating, engaging in conspiracy, or intentionally aiding the commission of an offence.
examples: Encouraging someone to commit arson is abetment.
Supplying tools knowing they will be used for burglary is abetment.

description: Sets liability for abettors, often similar to the principal offence, with adjustments as specified.
examples: A person who planned a robbery can get similar punishment as the robber.
Abetting a minor’s offence leads to liability even if the minor is not punished.

description: Criminalizes agreements to commit offences, even if the act is not completed, when the law so provides.
examples: Two people agree to counterfeit currency and start preparations.
A group plans a large fraud and takes steps like creating shell firms.

description: Punishes attempts to commit offences where the act goes beyond mere preparation but falls short of completion.
examples: Trying to pick a lock but getting caught is an attempt to commit house-breaking.
Administering poison that fails to kill is attempted murder.

description: Consent is invalid if given under fear, coercion, fraud, or misunderstanding of facts.
examples: Consent to sexual activity obtained by impersonation is invalid.
Agreeing to a contract because of a critical lie voids 'consent'.

section_title: Act done by mistake of fact
description: Protects a person who, acting in good faith, does an act by mistake of fact and not by mistake of law in certain cases.
examples: A person takes another’s umbrella genuinely believing it to be theirs.
A guard arrests someone believing they match a wanted description in good faith.

description: Recognizes that acts done to avoid greater harm may be excused when done in good faith and proportionately.
examples: Breaking a car window to rescue a baby in heat.
Trespassing briefly to warn of a gas leak and evacuate people.

description: Allows reasonable force to protect one’s body or property, or that of others, against certain offences, within limits.
examples: Pushing away an attacker to prevent assault.
Detaining a thief caught inside your house using reasonable force.

section_title: When right of private defence extends to causing death
description: Specifies grave situations where lethal force may be justified, such as preventing murder, rape, or grievous hurt, subject to necessity and proportionality.
examples: Using deadly force to stop an armed intruder threatening life.
Preventing a sexual assault where no lesser force would suffice.

description: Sets boundaries where private defence does not apply or ceases, such as when there is time to seek authorities or when force becomes excessive.
examples: Chasing and beating a fleeing thief after the danger has ended is not protected.
Using a weapon against a minor non-violent trespass is excessive.

description: Provides protection to public servants acting in good faith within their legal authority.
examples: A police officer lawfully seizing property under warrant is protected.
A health inspector closing a shop for violations in good faith is protected.

description: Explains when intoxication affects criminal responsibility, typically not excusing voluntary intoxication but relevant to intention.
examples: Voluntarily drunk driving causing injury is not excused by intoxication.
Involuntary intoxication may negate intent in rare cases.

description: Provides a defence when, due to mental illness, the person was incapable of understanding the nature of the act or that it was wrong or unlawful.
examples: A person in psychosis not understanding their act may be exempt.
A proven severe mental disorder at the time can negate criminal intent.

description: Sets age-related rules for criminal responsibility, recognizing that children below a certain age may not have requisite intent.
examples: A 9-year-old taking a toy is not criminally liable.
A 12-year-old’s capacity is assessed based on understanding.

description: Acts done by accident without criminal intention or knowledge in lawful acts with lawful means and proper care may be excused.
examples: Accidentally injuring someone while performing a lawful sport with due care.
Tripping and causing minor damage unintentionally during normal activity.

description: Protects good faith communications made for the benefit of the person receiving them.
examples: A doctor warns a patient about a serious risk in blunt terms, acting in good faith.
A teacher informs parents about a student’s dangerous behavior to protect them.

description: Clarifies that confessions obtained by inducement, threat, or promise, or without safeguards, are unreliable and restricted by law.
examples: A confession under police pressure is inadmissible.
An accused’s voluntary statement with safeguards may be considered.

description: Recognizes electronic records, signatures, and digital evidence, harmonizing with IT law for offences and proof.
examples: A digitally signed contract is treated as a valid document.
Chat logs and server records may be used as electronic evidence.

description: Extends application to offences on Indian ships, aircraft, and possibly territorial waters as defined.
examples: An assault on an Indian flight over international airspace is triable in India.
Smuggling on an Indian-registered ship falls under Indian jurisdiction.

description: Defines unlawful assembly and liability where a group with a shared unlawful object commits offences.
examples: A mob gathers to vandalize property; all members may be liable.
Violence during a banned assembly leads to group liability.

description: Deals with acts that cause common injury or annoyance to the public or obstruct public rights.
examples: Dumping toxic waste that pollutes a neighborhood water source.
Blocking a public road without permission causing widespread disruption.

description: Criminalizes obscene, indecent content distribution or public display, with modern consideration for digital media.
examples: Selling explicit obscene videos to minors.
Posting obscene content publicly on social media.

description: Punishes making or publishing false imputations harming a person’s reputation, with exceptions for good faith opinion, truth for public good, and privilege.
examples: Publishing a false article accusing someone of bribery without proof.
Spreading a baseless rumor that harms a teacher’s reputation.

description: Threatening someone with injury to person, reputation, or property to cause alarm or force action or inaction.
examples: Threatening to release private photos unless money is paid.
Threatening harm to a shopkeeper to force a discount.

section_title: Insult and provocation to breach of peace
description: Punishes deliberate insults and provocations intended or likely to cause a breach of peace.
examples: Using fighting words in public to provoke a brawl.
Displaying inflammatory posters to incite a scuffle.

description: When two or more persons fight in a public place, disturbing public peace, all are liable.
examples: Two people fistfight on a busy road, causing panic.
A group brawl in a market creating public disturbance.

description: Making a false document or electronic record with intent to cause damage, support a claim, or commit fraud.
examples: Altering a mark-sheet to show higher grades.
Creating a fake company seal to sign contracts.

section_title: Using as genuine a forged document
description: Knowingly using a forged document as if it were genuine is an offence.
examples: Submitting a forged salary slip for a loan.
Presenting a fake birth certificate to get a passport.

description: Criminalizes making, possessing, or trafficking counterfeit currency or instruments, with enhanced penalties.
examples: Printing fake ₹500 notes.
Carrying a bundle of counterfeit notes for distribution.

section_title: Possession of instruments or materials for forging or counterfeiting
description: Having tools or materials intended for forgery or counterfeiting is punishable.
examples: Possessing specialized plates to print fake notes.
Storing hologram stickers to counterfeit branded goods.

description: Deceiving a person to deliver property or to consent to retain property, or to do/omit something they wouldn’t otherwise do, causing damage.
examples: Promising a job to extract money with no intention to deliver.
Selling a fake product claiming it is genuine to get payment.

description: Cheating by pretending to be another person or falsely representing to be someone else.
examples: Impersonating a government officer to collect 'fees'.
Using someone’s identity to obtain a SIM card.

description: Dishonestly misappropriating or converting to one’s own use property entrusted to them, or violating any legal direction of trust.
examples: A cashier keeps customer payments instead of depositing them.
A trustee uses trust funds for personal expenses.

description: Dishonestly taking or using movable property for oneself that belongs to another, without consent.
examples: Keeping a found phone and selling it instead of returning it.
Using office equipment for personal profit without permission.

description: Receiving or retaining stolen property knowing or having reason to believe it to be stolen.
examples: Buying a laptop at a suspiciously low price from a stranger.
Holding goods for a friend while knowing they were stolen.

description: Dishonestly taking movable property out of someone’s possession without consent.
examples: Stealing a phone from a café table.
Taking cash from a roommate’s wallet without permission.

description: A form of theft involving sudden grabbing, often from the person, causing surprise without grievous force.
examples: Snatching a chain from someone’s neck and running.
Grabbing a phone from a person’s hand in traffic.

description: Intentionally putting a person in fear of injury to induce them to deliver property or valuable security.
examples: Threatening to harm a shop unless they pay 'protection money'.
Blackmailing with private information to get cash.

description: Theft or extortion becomes robbery when there is imminent fear or actual violence during the act.
examples: Pointing a knife to take a wallet from a victim.
Beating someone until they transfer money via UPI.

description: Robbery committed by five or more persons acting together.
examples: A gang of six breaks into a house and robs the family.
An armed group stops a car convoy and loots valuables.

description: Entering into or remaining in any building or premises used as a human dwelling or place of custody of property with intent to commit an offence.
examples: Breaking into a home to steal.
Entering a warehouse at night intending to commit theft.

description: House-trespass with specific aggravating methods like breaking open entry, using force, or at certain times.
examples: Entering by breaking a window at night to steal.
Using a duplicate key secretly to commit theft inside.

description: Causing destruction or change to property with intent to cause wrongful loss or damage.
examples: Damaging a rival shop’s signboard.
Spoiling stored grain by contaminating it.

description: Entering or remaining on property unlawfully to commit an offence, intimidate, insult, or annoy.
examples: Entering a neighbor’s yard after being told not to.
Staying inside an office after hours intending to steal.

description: An act causing another to apprehend immediate use of criminal force.
examples: Raising a fist to strike someone, making them fear a hit.
Lunging with a stick as if to strike.

description: Intentional use of force to any person without consent, in order to commit an offence or cause injury, fear, or annoyance.
examples: Pushing someone out of a queue intentionally.
Throwing water on someone to humiliate them.

description: Causing bodily pain, disease, or infirmity to any person.
examples: Slapping someone causing pain.
Injecting a person with a harmful substance causing illness.

description: Causing serious bodily harm like permanent disfigurement, fracture, or severe injury as defined.
examples: Breaking someone’s arm in a fight.
Throwing acid causing permanent facial scars.

description: Unlawfully obstructing a person so they cannot proceed in a direction they have a right to go.
examples: Blocking a coworker from exiting a room.
Standing in front of a scooter to stop the rider unlawfully.

description: Wrongfully restraining a person in a way that prevents them from going beyond certain limits.
examples: Locking a tenant inside their room over a rent dispute.
Detaining a customer in a back room without legal authority.

description: Taking or enticing a person away without lawful authority; includes specific rules for minors and persons of unsound mind.
examples: Luring a minor from school without parental consent.
Taking a dependent adult away to control their property.

description: Compelling or inducing someone to go from any place by force or deceit.
examples: Forcing a person into a vehicle and driving off.
Deceiving someone to follow to a remote place for exploitation.

description: Recruiting, transporting, harboring, or receiving persons for exploitation by means like threat, coercion, abduction, fraud, deception, abuse of power, or inducement.
examples: Moving workers across states with confiscated IDs for forced labor.
Luring women with job offers for sexual exploitation.

description: Provides definitions used for sexual offences, including consent, penetrative acts, and circumstances vitiating consent.
examples: Clarifying when consent is valid in a rape case.
Defining acts that constitute penetrative sexual assault.

description: Defines rape, circumstances where consent is invalid, and prescribes punishments with graded severity for aggravated forms.
examples: Sexual intercourse without consent.
Rape of a minor triggers enhanced punishment.

description: Punishes gang rape and specific aggravated circumstances with higher minimum sentences.
examples: Multiple offenders sexually assault a victim together.
Rape causing grievous injury attracts enhanced penalties.

description: Covers acts like unwelcome physical contact, stalking, showing pornography without consent, and other harassment.
examples: Touching a woman inappropriately in public.
Sending explicit images repeatedly without consent.

description: Criminalizes watching or capturing images of a person in private acts without consent, and persistently following or contacting despite disinterest.
examples: Filming someone bathing without consent.
Following a person daily and messaging them despite clear refusal.

section_title: Adultery and marital sexual offences (as defined)
description: Addresses specified marital context offences as enacted in BNS, aligned with Supreme Court rulings removing criminal adultery against consenting adults.
examples: Where applicable, punishes conduct specifically criminalized post-judgment.
No prosecution for consensual adult adultery in line with precedent.

description: Death caused by rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide.
examples: A driver speeding through a red light causes a fatal crash.
Negligent handling of industrial machinery leads to a worker’s death.

description: Causing death with the intention of causing death, or with knowledge that the act is likely to cause death, but not meeting the full definition of murder.
examples: Beating someone knowing it could be fatal, but without intent to kill.
Firing a gun into a crowd causing death with knowledge of likely consequences.

description: Culpable homicide becomes murder when done with specific, higher degrees of intent or in specified circumstances.
examples: Stabbing a person in the chest to kill.
Poisoning a rival with clear intent to cause death.

description: Encouraging or aiding someone to commit suicide is punishable.
examples: Constantly instigating and supplying means to a victim to end their life.
Blackmailing a person to the point of suicide and aiding it.

description: Doing an act with intent to cause death that falls short of killing is attempt to murder.
examples: Shooting at someone but missing.
Stabbing a person in a vital area but they survive.

section_title: Causing miscarriage and offences against unborn children
description: Criminalizes causing miscarriage without lawful reason and certain acts endangering an unborn child, consistent with medical law exceptions.
examples: Assaulting a pregnant woman causing miscarriage.
Administering drugs to terminate pregnancy without medical authorization.

section_title: Hurt by dangerous weapons or means
description: Enhanced punishment when hurt is caused by dangerous weapons, acid, fire, or similar means.
examples: Attacking with a knife causing injuries.
Throwing acid causing burns.

description: Specific offence for using acid to cause harm, with stringent minimum sentences and rehabilitation/compensation considerations.
examples: Throwing acid on someone after a rejected proposal.
Supplying acid knowing it will be used for an attack.

section_title: Rash or negligent act causing hurt
description: Punishes rash or negligent acts that cause hurt but not grievous hurt or death.
examples: Recklessly flying a drone that injures a passerby.
Negligently handling fireworks causing minor burns.

section_title: Dowry death and cruelty related to marriage (as specified)
description: Addresses dowry death and cruelty to a married woman by husband or relatives, with presumptions and enhanced penalties in defined situations.
examples: A woman dies under suspicious circumstances after dowry harassment.
Repeated cruelty by in-laws linked to dowry demands.

section_title: Cruelty by husband or relatives of husband
description: Punishes cruelty to a married woman by her husband or his relatives, including harassment for unlawful demands or conduct likely to drive her to suicide or cause grave injury.
examples: Relatives repeatedly harass a woman to bring more dowry.
Husband subjects wife to sustained physical and mental abuse causing severe trauma.

description: Taking or detaining a person and demanding money, property, or other benefit for their release.
examples: Abducting a businessman and demanding ₹50 lakh.
Holding a child and threatening harm unless payment is made.

description: Kidnapping or maiming a person, particularly minors, to exploit them for begging is a serious offence with enhanced punishment.
examples: Forcing a child to beg at traffic lights after abducting them.
Injuring a person to evoke sympathy and collect money.

description: Prohibits selling, purchasing, or compelling any person into slavery, servitude, or forced labour.
examples: Confiscating workers’ IDs and forcing them to work without pay.
Selling a person into bonded labour to repay an inflated debt.

description: Criminalizes specific non-consensual or exploitative sexual acts as defined by law, in line with constitutional protections for consenting adults.
examples: Sexual assault involving acts defined as unnatural without consent.
Exploitative acts against minors under this head.

description: Deliberately and maliciously insulting the religion or religious beliefs of any class of citizens with intent to outrage their feelings.
examples: Publishing a targeted, malicious insult of a religion to provoke anger.
Desecrating a place of worship to inflame sentiments.

description: Acts that promote enmity, hatred, or ill-will between different groups on grounds like religion, race, language, etc., or that disturb harmony.
examples: Spreading hateful pamphlets urging violence against a community.
Inciting crowds with speeches that pit one group against another.

description: Publishing or circulating statements or rumours with intent to cause fear, alarm, or disturbances, or to induce offences against the State or public order.
examples: Circulating false panic-inducing messages about a bank run.
Spreading fabricated communal rumours to cause riots.

section_title: Seductive or exploitative material targeting minors
description: Prohibits creating, possessing, or distributing sexual or exploitative content involving minors, with stringent penalties.
examples: Sharing explicit images of a minor online.
Possessing child sexual abuse material for distribution.

description: Voluntarily obstructing a public servant in the discharge of their public functions.
examples: Blocking a health inspector from entering premises during inspection.
Physically stopping a police officer from making a lawful arrest.

section_title: Assault or criminal force to deter public servant
description: Using assault or criminal force to deter or prevent a public servant from performing official duty.
examples: Shoving a traffic cop who is issuing a challan.
Throwing objects at a tax officer during a raid.

description: Falsely pretending to be a public servant and acting in that capacity.
examples: Posing as a municipal officer to extort 'fines'.
Impersonating a police officer to search a house.

section_title: Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant
description: Knowingly disobeying a lawful order issued by a competent public servant to prevent obstruction, injury, or disturbance.
examples: Defying a curfew order during a riot.
Ignoring a building evacuation order during a gas leak.

description: Giving or offering gratification to a public servant to influence official acts, separate from specialized anti-corruption laws.
examples: Offering cash to get a licence approved faster.
Paying a bribe to avoid a regulatory penalty.

description: Public servant accepting gratification other than legal remuneration as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing official acts.
examples: An officer accepts money to overlook violations.
A clerk takes a 'fee' for issuing a certificate quickly.

section_title: Public servant unlawfully buying or bidding
description: Public servants misusing position to buy property or bid in auctions connected with their official duties.
examples: An officer overseeing a land auction secretly bids via a proxy.
A procurement official buys from a vendor they regulate.

description: Preparing or signing any document knowing it to be incorrect to cause injury or benefit.
examples: Issuing a false inspection certificate.
Backdating an official order to favor a party.

section_title: Omission by public servant to apprehend or proceed against offender
description: A public servant deliberately fails to apprehend an offender or intentionally omits steps required by law.
examples: A police officer ignores an arrest warrant for a bribe.
An inspector avoids issuing a mandatory closure order despite violations.

section_title: Escape or rescue from lawful custody
description: Whoever escapes from lawful custody, or whoever rescues or attempts to rescue a person from such custody.
examples: Breaking out of a police lock-up.
Friends overpower guards to free a detainee.

description: Harbouring a person known or believed to have committed an offence to shield them from legal consequences.
examples: Hiding a fugitive in your house.
Providing resources to help a convict avoid capture.

section_title: Giving false information to public servant
description: Knowingly providing false information to a public servant to cause them to use their lawful power to the injury of another.
examples: Filing a false complaint to get a rival arrested.
Submitting fake documents to obtain a government benefit.

description: Giving false evidence in judicial proceedings or making false statements under oath/affirmation.
examples: Lying under oath about an alibi.
Submitting an affidavit with knowingly false facts.

description: Creating false documents, records, or circumstances to mislead courts or authorities.
examples: Planting forged bills to implicate a shopkeeper.
Editing CCTV footage to fabricate a timeline.

description: Causing any evidence of an offence to disappear or giving false information to shield an offender from punishment.
examples: Destroying blood-stained clothes after a crime.
Cleaning a crime scene to erase fingerprints.

section_title: Waging war against the Government of India
description: Acts of waging war, attempting to wage war, or abetting waging war against India.
examples: Organizing armed attacks against state forces.
Supplying arms to a group to wage war on the State.

section_title: Conspiracy to commit offences against the State
description: Conspiring to wage war or commit serious offences against the State’s sovereignty and security.
examples: Planning coordinated attacks on military bases.
Plotting to sabotage critical infrastructure.

section_title: Sedition-like acts affecting sovereignty, unity and integrity
description: Punishes acts with intent to endanger sovereignty, unity and integrity of India by incitement to violence or public disorder, in the form specified by the statute.
examples: Inciting violent uprising against the State.
Organized calls for armed secession causing public disorder.

section_title: Assault on President, Governor, etc., to compel or restrain the exercise of any lawful power
description: Using criminal force against high constitutional authorities to influence their lawful powers.
examples: Attacking a Governor to force withdrawal of assent.
Assaulting the President’s staff to obstruct an official act.

section_title: Public tranquillity: unlawful assembly and rioting
description: Defines rioting and punishes members who use force or violence in pursuit of a common unlawful purpose.
examples: A mob damages vehicles during a protest.
Group attacks on shops under a common plan.

section_title: Arms and deadly weapons in unlawful assembly
description: Enhanced punishment when members of an unlawful assembly carry deadly weapons.
examples: Rioters carry swords and guns.
A group brings petrol bombs to a protest turned violent.

section_title: Harbouring persons hired for unlawful assembly
description: Harbouring individuals hired or employed to join unlawful assemblies or riots.
examples: Providing shelter to hired goons before a planned riot.
Paying and hosting outsiders to swell a violent crowd.

section_title: Promoting enmity during elections and public gatherings
description: Using elections or mass events to promote hatred or disturb public harmony attracts punishment under public order offences.
examples: Spreading communal hate during a campaign rally.
Provoking clashes at a festival gathering.

section_title: Public nuisance affecting health, safety or convenience
description: Acts or omissions that cause common injury, danger, or annoyance to the public or obstruct public rights.
examples: Releasing untreated sewage into a public drain.
Blocking a busy road with unauthorized construction.

section_title: Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale
description: Adulterating food or drink so as to make it noxious or harmful, or selling such items knowing them to be adulterated.
examples: Adding harmful chemicals to milk to increase volume.
Selling oil mixed with unsafe substances as edible oil.

section_title: Sale of noxious food or drink
description: Selling food or drink that is unfit for consumption or harmful, regardless of adulteration method.
examples: Selling spoiled meat as fresh.
Selling homemade liquor contaminated with methanol.

description: Adulterating drugs or medical preparations to reduce quality or make them harmful, or selling/possessing such drugs.
examples: Diluting antibiotics with inert powder.
Selling counterfeit painkillers with toxic fillers.

description: Selling or offering for sale any adulterated or spurious drugs knowing or with reason to believe them to be such.
examples: A pharmacist knowingly sells counterfeit tablets.
A distributor circulates fake vaccines.

section_title: Rash or negligent act endangering life or personal safety
description: Doing any rash or negligent act that endangers human life or personal safety of others.
examples: Flying drones over crowds dangerously.
Leaving live electrical wires exposed in a public area.

section_title: Public servants disobeying directions under law
description: Public servants who knowingly disobey legal directions intending to save a person from punishment or property from forfeiture.
examples: Officer ignores court attachment orders to protect a debtor.
Police refuse to register a mandated case to shield an offender.

section_title: Omission to give information of offence to public servant
description: Legally bound persons who intentionally omit to give information about certain offences to authorities.
examples: A hospital conceals a medico-legal injury case.
A manager fails to report a serious workplace accident required by law.

section_title: Giving or fabricating false information to cause public servant to use power wrongfully
description: Providing or creating false information intending that a public servant uses lawful power to harm or annoy someone.
examples: Forging a complaint to get a competitor’s shop sealed.
Submitting a fake medical report to block a licence.

section_title: Escape from confinement or custody through negligence
description: Custodial officers who negligently allow escape may be liable; escapees are separately liable.
examples: A guard leaves a cell unlocked leading to escape.
Transporting prisoners without restraints who then flee.

section_title: Concealment of design to commit offence
description: Knowing of a plan to commit an offence and intentionally concealing it when legally bound to inform authorities.
examples: Withholding knowledge of a planned dacoity from police.
Not reporting a known bomb plot despite duty.

description: Causing disappearance of evidence or fabricating evidence to mislead courts or investigations.
examples: Erasing CCTV recordings after a theft.
Creating fake call logs to establish an alibi.

description: Resisting lawful arrest or rescuing a person from such arrest is punishable.
examples: A suspect fights officers to avoid being handcuffed.
Friends block the police vehicle and free the detainee.

description: Applying for, voting, or acting in an election as another person, or abetting such personation.
examples: Casting a vote using someone else’s ID.
Aiding multiple fake voters during polling.

section_title: False statements in connection with elections
description: Making false statements or accounts relating to elections with intent to affect results or mislead authorities.
examples: Submitting false expense accounts to the election authority.
Announcing fabricated results to influence voters.

section_title: Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade
description: Public servants engaging in trade or business forbidden by their office or creating conflicts of interest.
examples: A judge running a private arbitration business while in office.
A tax officer trading in regulated commodities they oversee.

section_title: Disclosure of identity of victims and witnesses in protected offences
description: Publishing identity of victims in specified offences (like sexual offences) without legal authority is punishable.
examples: Revealing a rape survivor’s name in media.
Posting a victim’s address in an online forum.

description: Marrying again during the lifetime of a spouse when the first marriage is valid and subsisting, except under lawful exceptions.
examples: A man marries a second time without divorce from his first wife.
A woman enters a second marriage while her first is still valid.

section_title: Marriage ceremony fraudulently performed without lawful authority
description: Performing or officiating a marriage without lawful authority or knowing legal requirements are not met.
examples: A person conducts a sham marriage without required consents.
Officiating a marriage knowing one party is underage.

description: Concealing the fact of a prior subsisting marriage while contracting a second marriage.
examples: Hiding an existing marriage from a new spouse.
Suppressing divorce status to induce a new marriage.

section_title: Cruelty to animals and mischief by killing or maiming animals
description: Punishes killing, maiming, or rendering useless any animal of another, with cruelty or malice.
examples: Poisoning a neighbor’s dog out of spite.
Slashing a farmer’s cattle to cause loss.

section_title: Injury to or defilement of place of worship
description: Damaging, defiling, or trespassing in places of worship with intent to insult religion.
examples: Spray-painting insults inside a temple.
Breaking idols to provoke a community.

description: Trespassing on places set apart for funeral rites or sepulture with intent to insult or disturb.
examples: Disrupting a burial ceremony by entering and shouting slurs.
Damaging graves to offend mourners.

section_title: Maritime offences: piracy and depredation on the high seas
description: Punishes piracy, armed robbery, or depredation at sea, including aiding or abetting such acts.
examples: Hijacking a merchant ship on the high seas.
Organizing an armed raid on an offshore vessel.

section_title: Counterfeiting government stamps, currency marks, or seals
description: Counterfeiting or possessing instruments for counterfeiting government stamps, currency identifiers, or official seals.
examples: Printing fake revenue stamps.
Manufacturing counterfeit government seals for documents.

section_title: Using as genuine a counterfeit government instrument
description: Using counterfeit government stamps, seals, or marks as genuine is an offence.
examples: Affixing fake revenue stamps to agreements.
Using a forged government seal to authenticate a certificate.

description: Dishonestly altering, destroying, or fabricating accounts, books, or documents to defraud.
examples: Cooking company books to siphon funds.
Deleting ledger entries to hide embezzlement.

section_title: Criminal breach of contract of service
description: Breach of service contract with intent to cause wrongful loss or to endanger life, property, or public safety may attract criminal liability.
examples: A security guard abandons post to enable a planned theft.
A pilot deserts duty knowing it will endanger passengers.

section_title: Cheating involving electronic means or identity fraud
description: Cheating conducted through electronic communications or identity theft methods attracts punishment, in harmony with IT laws.
examples: Phishing victims via fake banking websites.
SIM-swap fraud to drain bank accounts.

section_title: House-trespass to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
description: House-trespass with intent to commit any imprisonable offence attracts enhanced punishment.
examples: Breaking into a home to commit sexual assault.
Entering a warehouse to sabotage equipment.

section_title: Voyeurism, image-based abuse, and distribution without consent
description: Capturing, sharing, or threatening to share intimate images without consent is punishable, with higher penalties for repeat offences.
examples: Sharing a partner’s private photos after a breakup.
Threatening to leak private images to extort money.

description: Repeatedly following, contacting, or monitoring a person despite clear disinterest, including via electronic means.
examples: Following a colleague from office to home daily.
Using spyware to track someone’s location and messages.

section_title: Sale or hire of minors for immoral purposes
description: Selling, letting to hire, or otherwise dealing with minors for prostitution or immoral purposes.
examples: Trafficking a minor to a brothel.
Renting a minor for sexual exploitation.

description: Procuring or inducing a minor to go from any place for unlawful sexual purposes.
examples: Luring a minor with gifts to a hotel for exploitation.
Arranging travel for a minor to another city for abuse.

section_title: Buying or disposing of any person as a slave
description: Buying, selling, transferring, or disposing of any person as if they were property.
examples: Selling a person to work without pay and freedom.
Purchasing a kidnapped person to force labour.

description: Compelling a person to labour against their will with threats or coercion.
examples: Confiscating wages and threatening violence if the worker leaves.
Forcing villagers to perform work without payment.

section_title: Hurt by corrosive substances other than acid
description: Punishes causing hurt using corrosive or harmful chemicals other than classic acid, recognizing varied attack methods.
examples: Throwing alkaline drain cleaner causing burns.
Using industrial solvent to injure someone’s face.

section_title: Murder by group or in course of organized crime (aggravation)
description: Enhanced punishment for murder committed by a group, in course of organized crime, or in specified aggravated contexts.
examples: Gang executes a rival as part of organized extortion.
Contract killing arranged by a criminal syndicate.

section_title: Homicide by rash or negligent driving
description: Causing death by rash or negligent driving of any vehicle, with graded punishment based on circumstances like intoxication or hit-and-run.
examples: Speeding drunk driver kills a pedestrian.
Truck driver flees after fatally hitting a cyclist.

section_title: Causing grievous hurt by rash or negligent act
description: Rash or negligent acts causing grievous hurt attract higher penalties.
examples: Unsafe demolition causes severe injuries to neighbors.
Negligent handling of fireworks blinds a bystander.

description: Participation in criminal organizations committing theft, robbery, or dacoity carries stiffer punishments.
examples: Joining a gang specialized in highway lootings.
Coordinating a series of ATM break-ins across districts.

section_title: Habitual offenders: theft, house-breaking, or receiving stolen property
description: Repeat offenders in property crimes face enhanced liabilities.
examples: A habitual burglar caught again faces higher punishment.
A fence routinely buying stolen goods is punished more severely.

section_title: Criminal breach of trust by public servant or banker
description: Enhanced punishment when breach of trust is by a public servant, banker, merchant, or agent.
examples: A bank manager misuses deposits for personal trading.
A public treasurer diverts funds to private accounts.

section_title: Dishonest or fraudulent removal of property to prevent seizure
description: Removing, concealing, or transferring property to prevent lawful seizure.
examples: Shifting goods at night to avoid attachment by court.
Transferring a car to a relative to evade repossession.

section_title: Fraudulent deeds and dispositions of property
description: Executing transfers to defeat creditors or legal claims is an offence.
examples: Gifting property to family to avoid paying debts.
Backdating a sale deed to frustrate a court decree.

section_title: Mischief by fire or explosive substance
description: Causing damage by fire or explosives attracts stringent penalties, especially endangering life or public property.
examples: Setting a warehouse on fire to claim insurance.
Using explosives to damage railway tracks.

section_title: Mischief causing damage to public infrastructure
description: Damaging roads, bridges, waterworks, or other public infrastructure is an aggravated form of mischief.
examples: Breaking streetlights across a neighborhood.
Damaging a water treatment plant’s equipment.

section_title: Tampering with public utilities and safety systems
description: Interfering with systems like electricity, gas, telecom, or emergency services that endangers life or service continuity.
examples: Cutting power lines to an area causing hazards.
Disabling fire suppression systems in a mall.

section_title: Fraudulent cancellation or destruction of valuable security
description: Fraudulently destroying, canceling, or secreting a valuable security or instrument to cause loss.
examples: Burning a promissory note to erase debt.
Destroying a signed cheque to prevent payment to the holder.

section_title: Forgery of valuable security, will, or authority to adopt
description: Forgery related to valuable securities, wills, or legal authorities carries higher punishment.
examples: Forging a will to inherit property.
Creating a fake power of attorney to transfer assets.

description: Possessing or trafficking counterfeit currency or instruments knowing them to be counterfeit.
examples: Supplying fake notes to small vendors.
Carrying bundles of counterfeit currency for exchange.

section_title: Making or possessing counterfeit seals, plates, or instruments
description: Making or possessing devices used to create counterfeit documents or currency.
examples: Owning plates to print fake passports.
Holding embossers to forge company seals.

section_title: Using forged or counterfeit documents in public office
description: Using forged documents in official processes is separately punishable.
examples: Submitting a fake caste certificate for reservation.
Using forged land records in court filings.

section_title: Affray and public fighting with weapons
description: Public fighting that disturbs peace, with aggravation when weapons are used.
examples: Two groups clash with sticks in a market.
Knife fight in a public square causing panic.

description: Obscene acts in public places or distribution of obscene material causing public annoyance.
examples: Displaying pornographic videos on a public screen.
Performing obscene gestures towards passersby.

description: Cheating or swindling in games, betting, or wagering, including electronic formats.
examples: Using hacks to win online betting fraudulently.
Marking cards in a gambling den to cheat players.

section_title: Insult intended to provoke breach of peace
description: Uttering words or gestures intended or likely to provoke a person to break the peace.
examples: Hurling targeted slurs to start a fight.
Throwing provocative insults at a rival team’s supporters.

section_title: Criminal intimidation by anonymous communication or electronic means
description: Threats delivered anonymously or through electronic messages attract punishment.
examples: Anonymous emails threatening violence unless paid.
Using a fake account to threaten to leak private data.

description: Extorting by threatening to accuse someone of an offence unless they deliver property.
examples: Threatening to file a false rape case unless money is paid.
Demanding cash by threatening a bogus corruption complaint.

section_title: Extortion by putting a person in fear of death or grievous hurt
description: Extortion involving threats of death or grievous hurt carries higher punishment.
examples: Threatening to shoot unless money is transferred.
Gang threatens to break a shopkeeper’s legs for protection money.

section_title: Robbery with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt
description: Robbery aggravated by attempts to cause death or grievous hurt, or actual causing thereof.
examples: Stabbing a victim during a wallet snatch.
Beating a victim severely to force a bank transfer.

description: When during dacoity, murder is committed, all participants may face enhanced punishment.
examples: A gang kills a guard while robbing a bank.
Home invasion by five where a resident is killed.

description: Receiving or dealing in property known to be obtained through dacoity.
examples: Buying jewelry from a known dacoity gang.
Storing loot from a highway robbery for resale.

section_title: Belonging to a gang of dacoits
description: Membership or association with a gang of dacoits is punishable.
examples: Being part of a group planning serial highway robberies.
Serving as a lookout for a dacoity gang.

description: Preparing to commit dacoity, such as assembling weapons or planning routes, is punishable.
examples: Stockpiling weapons and masks for a planned heist.
Reconnoitering a bank with a five-person team.

description: Making, possessing, or using counterfeit coins or government tokens is an offence.
examples: Minting fake ₹10 coins.
Using counterfeit tokens in public transport.

section_title: Using as genuine a counterfeit coin
description: Using counterfeit coin as if genuine, knowing or having reason to believe it to be counterfeit.
examples: Paying a shop with fake coins.
Feeding counterfeit coins into vending machines.

section_title: Possession of counterfeit coin with knowledge
description: Possessing counterfeit coins knowing them to be counterfeit and intending to use them as genuine.
examples: Carrying a bag of fake coins to circulate in markets.
Stocking counterfeit coins to pay street vendors.

section_title: Criminal breach of trust by carrier, warehouse-keeper, etc.
description: Entrusted carriers, warehouse-keepers, or similar custodians who dishonestly misappropriate or convert entrusted goods are liable to enhanced punishment.
examples: A courier company diverts parcels to sell the contents.
A warehouse operator secretly sells stored goods.

section_title: Criminal breach of trust by clerk or servant
description: Clerks or employees who dishonestly misappropriate employer’s property entrusted to them are punished more severely.
examples: An accounts assistant transfers client refunds to a personal account.
A store clerk skims cash from daily sales.

section_title: Possession of property suspected to be stolen
description: Having property reasonably suspected to be stolen and failing to account for its possession can be punishable.
examples: Found with multiple new phones without bills and no credible explanation.
Holding jewelry with tampered serials and inconsistent story.

description: Concealing or keeping stolen property knowing or having reason to believe it to be stolen.
examples: Hiding a friend’s stolen laptop in your house.
Storing stolen bikes in a rented garage.

section_title: Criminal trespass with preparation for causing hurt
description: Trespass accompanied by preparation for causing hurt or restraint attracts higher punishment.
examples: Entering a house with weapons to intimidate residents.
Trespassing with ropes and tape to tie occupants.

section_title: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night
description: Secret or forceful entry into a dwelling at night is punished more severely.
examples: Breaking a window at midnight to steal.
Entering stealthily after dark to commit theft.

section_title: Robbery or dacoity with attempt to cause death
description: During robbery/dacoity, attempting to cause death or grievous hurt is an aggravating factor.
examples: Pointing a loaded gun and pulling the trigger but misfiring.
Swinging a machete at a victim during a robbery.

section_title: Collecting arms, etc., with intention to wage war
description: Collecting men, arms, or ammunition with intent to wage war against the Government is punishable.
examples: Stockpiling rifles to mount attacks on security forces.
Training cadres and amassing explosives for insurrection.

section_title: Assaulting public servant to obstruct duty during riots
description: Assaulting or obstructing public servants during riots or unlawful assemblies attracts higher penalties.
examples: Attacking firefighters trying to douse a riot fire.
Assaulting police dispersing a violent crowd.

section_title: Public nuisance by negligent acts likely to spread infection
description: Negligent acts likely to spread disease dangerous to life constitute an offence.
examples: Knowingly violating quarantine rules and mingling in public.
Operating a business while symptomatic in a declared outbreak.

description: Instituting or causing to be instituted false criminal proceedings with intent to injure.
examples: Filing a fake theft FIR against a rival to harm reputation.
Coercing a witness to lodge a false complaint.

section_title: Defamation: printing or sale of defamatory material
description: Printing, engraving, or selling material containing defamatory matter, knowing it to be defamatory.
examples: Publishing a pamphlet with false allegations to damage reputation.
Selling a magazine issue known to carry defamatory content.

description: Forging documents specifically to cheat or defraud another person.
examples: Creating fake bank statements to obtain a loan.
Forging a property deed to sell land you don’t own.

section_title: Making or possessing counterfeit currency notes or instruments
description: Manufacturing or possessing counterfeit currency notes or instruments with intent to use them as genuine is punishable.
examples: Running a clandestine currency-printing setup.
Keeping stacks of high-quality fake notes for circulation.

section_title: Cheating with knowledge that wrongful loss may ensue
description: Cheating where the offender knows it is likely to cause wrongful loss to the person deceived.
examples: Selling a car with tampered odometer knowing the buyer will overpay.
Misrepresenting critical defects in a house sale.

section_title: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property
description: Deceiving a person and dishonestly inducing them to deliver property or valuable security.
examples: Impersonating a bank official to get OTPs and drain funds.
Convincing a victim to transfer money to a 'safe account'.

section_title: Matrimonial cruelty and dowry harassment: aggravated cases
description: Aggravated forms of cruelty or harassment relating to dowry with specified presumptions and penalties.
examples: Sustained harassment leading to serious injury or attempt to suicide.
Demanding large sums with threats of expulsion from the home.

section_title: Hurt by dangerous weapons with intent to disfigure or disable
description: Causing hurt using dangerous weapons with intent to permanently disfigure or disable attracts higher penalties.
examples: Slashing a face intending permanent scarring.
Attacking hands with a blade to disable fingers.

description: Causing grievous hurt with dangerous weapons, including fractures, emasculation, or permanent loss of senses.
examples: Breaking a leg with an iron rod.
Blinding someone with a chemical thrown in the eyes.

section_title: Maiming by corrosive substances or fire
description: Using corrosive substances or fire to maim or cause grievous disfigurement.
examples: Throwing caustic soda to burn skin deeply.
Setting someone on fire causing lasting deformities.

description: Snatching accompanied by violence or causing hurt is punished more severely.
examples: Dragging a victim with a bike while snatching a bag.
Punching a person to grab their phone.

section_title: Theft in dwelling house or place of worship
description: Theft committed in a dwelling house, place of worship, or custody place attracts enhanced punishment.
examples: Stealing jewelry from a home safe.
Taking donation money from a temple box.

description: Employee theft from employer’s possession is specially punished.
examples: A cashier quietly pockets part of the day’s collection.
A warehouse staffer steals inventory items regularly.

section_title: Theft after preparation for causing death or hurt
description: Theft where the offender makes preparation for causing death, hurt, or restraint if resisted.
examples: Carrying a knife to threaten a victim during theft.
Planning to tie up residents if confronted.

description: Robbery committed on a highway during nighttime is an aggravated offence.
examples: Stopping cars at night to loot passengers.
Holding up a trucker on a deserted highway after dark.

description: House-breaking committed during night time attracts greater punishment.
examples: Entering a home via roof at night to steal.
Breaking a backdoor lock after midnight.

section_title: Criminal trespass into place of worship or custody
description: Trespass into places of worship or where property is kept with intent to commit an offence.
examples: Entering a temple’s inner room to steal idols.
Trespassing into a bank’s vault area.

section_title: Mischief by killing or maiming cattle
description: Causing death or maiming of cattle or valuable livestock constituting mischief.
examples: Poisoning a neighbor’s cows.
Cutting tendons of a bull to disable it.

section_title: Mischief by fire or explosive with intent to destroy dwelling
description: Setting fire or using explosives intending to destroy a dwelling or make it unsafe.
examples: Arson targeting a rival’s home.
Planting an explosive to collapse a house wall.

section_title: Mischief to public property by fire or explosive
description: Damaging public property through fire or explosives attracts stringent penalties.
examples: Burning buses during protests.
Blowing up electrical transformers.

section_title: Mischief causing diminution of water supply
description: Acts that corrupt or diminish water supply to the public or a community.
examples: Breaking pipes feeding a village’s only water tank.
Polluting a reservoir to render water unusable.

section_title: Mischief to works of irrigation or public drainage
description: Damaging canals, embankments, or drainage systems affecting public utility.
examples: Breaching a canal bund to flood fields.
Blocking a public drainage leading to flooding.

section_title: Mischief to telegraph, telephone, or electronic communication lines
description: Destroying or tampering with communication lines or infrastructure.
examples: Cutting fiber optic cables to disrupt internet.
Damaging mobile towers’ cables during unrest.

section_title: Mischief to railway, aircraft, or navigation works
description: Damaging tracks, signals, aircraft systems, or navigation aids, endangering safety.
examples: Removing fishplates to derail a train.
Tampering with airport runway lights.

section_title: Mischief by injury to public road, bridge, or river
description: Acts causing damage to roads, bridges, rivers or navigable channels.
examples: Digging a trench across a public road.
Dumping debris to block a navigable canal.

section_title: Mischief by injury to works of art or historical monuments
description: Damaging statues, heritage sites, or public art.
examples: Defacing a protected monument with acid.
Breaking parts of a historical statue.

description: Aggravated intimidation involving threats to cause death, grievous hurt, arson, or to a woman’s modesty attracts higher punishment.
examples: Threatening to burn a family’s house unless paid.
Threatening sexual violence to force compliance.

section_title: Word, gesture or act intended to insult modesty
description: Intentionally insulting the modesty of a person through words, gestures, or acts.
examples: Making lewd gestures at someone in public.
Shouting sexually suggestive remarks to humiliate.

description: Obscene acts, songs, or material in public places causing annoyance or violating decency.
examples: Playing obscene videos loudly in public.
Singing vulgar songs to offend passersby.

section_title: Statements creating or promoting enmity, hatred or ill-will
description: Publishing or making statements promoting enmity between groups, or prejudicial to harmony, with intent and likelihood of public disorder.
examples: Posting inflammatory content targeting a community.
Delivering a speech urging hostility against a linguistic group.

section_title: Deliberate and malicious acts intended to outrage religious feelings
description: Deliberate insults or acts intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting their religion or beliefs.
examples: Destroying religious texts to provoke.
Posting malicious caricatures to inflame devotees.

section_title: Promoting enmity at places of worship or during ceremonies
description: Acts at religious places or during ceremonies that promote enmity or disturb harmony.
examples: Provocations during a procession to start clashes.
Inciting one group against another in a shrine.

section_title: Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking with preparation for hurt
description: Secret or forceful entry with preparation to cause hurt, restraint, or fear.
examples: Entering with duct tape and weapons to subdue residents.
Carrying chilli powder to blind victims during burglary.

description: Attempting robbery by taking steps beyond preparation, even if not completed.
examples: Pointing a knife and demanding a wallet before being caught.
Tying up a victim but fleeing before taking valuables.

description: Attempting dacoity with five or more persons taking overt steps.
examples: A group of five arrives armed at the target but is intercepted.
Breaking into a bank vault room before being foiled.

description: Preparatory acts for dacoity such as gathering weapons or planning routes are punishable.
examples: Mapping guard shifts and escape routes.
Acquiring vehicles with fake plates for the heist.

section_title: Belonging to a gang of thieves
description: Membership of a gang associated for theft is an offence.
examples: Being part of an organized pickpocket ring.
Serving as a safe-house operator for a theft gang.

description: Habitual receivers, disposers, or dealers in stolen property are punished more severely.
examples: Running a shop that routinely buys stolen phones.
Operating an online channel to resell stolen bikes.

section_title: Assault with intent to wrongfully confine
description: Assaulting someone with the intention of wrongfully confining them.
examples: Beating a debtor to lock him in a room.
Attacking a worker to force them into a factory dorm.

description: Wrongfully confining a person to extort property or valuable security.
examples: Detaining a businessman until he signs over assets.
Locking someone to force a digital transfer.

description: Taking or detaining any person with intent to demand ransom for release.
examples: Abducting a child and demanding money for return.
Detaining a tourist and negotiating a payoff.

description: Kidnapping or abducting with intent to murder or put the person in danger of being murdered.
examples: Forcing a rival into a car to drive to a remote spot for execution.
Abducting a witness intending to kill them.

section_title: Kidnapping or abduction to cause hurt or slavery
description: Kidnapping or abducting with intent to cause hurt, slavery, or unnatural lust.
examples: Abducting a worker for bonded labour.
Kidnapping to force manual labour with beatings.

description: Aggravated trafficking involving minors, organized groups, or cross-border movement carries enhanced punishment.
examples: Trafficking minors across states for sex work.
Organized ring transporting workers for forced labour.

section_title: Import, export, sale or distribution of obscene material
description: Dealing in obscene or indecent material for commercial gain is punishable, with higher penalties for minors’ involvement.
examples: Running a subscription site with obscene content targeting teens.
Importing obscene videos for sale.

description: Knowingly disobeying quarantine or containment rules lawfully made by public authority.
examples: Skipping mandated home isolation despite being COVID-positive.
Running a public event during a legally declared containment.

section_title: Negligent act likely to spread infection
description: Negligent acts likely to spread infectious disease dangerous to life.
examples: Restaurant keeps working with a contagious kitchen staff.
Ignoring sanitation protocols in a hospital ward.

section_title: Sale of adulterated seeds or agricultural inputs
description: Selling adulterated or spurious seeds/fertilizers/pesticides likely to cause crop failure.
examples: Selling fake high-yield seeds to farmers.
Supplying diluted pesticide that ruins crops.

description: Interfering with vaccination, sanitation, or disease control programs to the detriment of public health.
examples: Destroying vaccine vials at a clinic.
Sabotaging municipal fogging operations.

section_title: Attempt to commit murder by life convict
description: A life convict attempting to commit murder faces enhanced penalties.
examples: A life-term prisoner attacks a guard intending to kill.
A life convict stabs a fellow inmate in a lethal manner.

section_title: Threatening or bribing to screen offender
description: Threatening, bribing, or inducing a person to conceal or screen an offender from legal punishment.
examples: Paying a witness to destroy evidence.
Threatening a neighbor to stay silent about a crime.

description: Ignoring a court’s proclamation requiring appearance is punishable.
examples: Not appearing in court after public proclamation in a case.
Evading court despite being declared a proclaimed offender.

section_title: Absconding to avoid service of summons or warrant
description: Deliberately hiding or leaving jurisdiction to avoid legal process.
examples: Moving cities to avoid arrest on a warrant.
Changing identity to dodge court summons.

section_title: Resistance to taking of property by lawful authority
description: Resisting or obstructing seizure of property by lawful authority is punishable.
examples: Blocking officials from attaching property under court order.
Forming a crowd to prevent sealing of a shop by authorities.

section_title: Contempt of lawful authority of public servants
description: Disobedience or obstruction of orders promulgated by public servants maintaining public order or safety.
examples: Defying Section 144 prohibitory orders.
Ignoring evacuation orders during a dam breach warning.

description: Threatening or insulting a public servant to compel or deter them from duty.
examples: Threatening a tax inspector to drop a case.
Abusing a judge to influence a ruling.

section_title: Bribery in private sector causing public harm
description: Corrupt inducements in private organizations that cause public harm or safety risks are punishable under specified conditions.
examples: Bribing a lab technician to falsify safety tests.
Paying kickbacks to overlook building safety norms.

section_title: False claim to hold public office
description: Falsely claiming to hold a public office to gain advantage or influence others.
examples: Claiming to be an IAS officer to intimidate.
Pretending to be a food inspector to obtain free meals.

description: Altering or destroying government records or entries with intent to cause injury or gain.
examples: Changing land records to benefit a buyer.
Deleting registry entries to erase encumbrances.

section_title: Offences relating to weights and measures: fraud
description: Using false weights or measures or tampering with them to cheat consumers.
examples: Fuel pump rigged to deliver less than shown.
Grocery shop uses underweight scales.

description: Counterfeiting property marks used by manufacturers or owners to indicate property or quality.
examples: Imitating a brand’s quality seal.
Copying a factory’s proprietary mark to pass off goods.

section_title: Using as genuine a counterfeit property mark
description: Using counterfeit property marks as genuine to sell goods.
examples: Selling garments with fake brand tags.
Affixing counterfeit ISI marks to appliances.

section_title: Tampering with evidence in electronic form
description: Destroying, altering, or manipulating electronic records to mislead investigations or courts.
examples: Wiping phone data after receiving a legal hold notice.
Editing server logs to hide unauthorized access.

section_title: Identity theft and impersonation using electronic means
description: Stealing identity information and impersonating others electronically for fraud.
examples: Using stolen Aadhaar and PAN to open bank accounts.
SIM cloning to access OTPs and transfer funds.

description: Persistent online harassment, monitoring, or threats using digital platforms.
examples: Creating multiple accounts to harass someone online.
Doxxing and threats across platforms to silence a critic.

section_title: Publishing false electronic statements causing public mischief
description: Publishing false electronic content likely to cause panic, riots, or harm to public order.
examples: Spreading fake news about bank failures causing rushes.
False alerts about communal attacks inciting violence.

description: Interfering with systems designated as critical information infrastructure endangering national security or economy.
examples: Hacking power grid control systems.
Disabling air traffic control software.

description: Providing funds, property, or services to support terrorist acts or groups is punishable under special laws and referenced here.
examples: Transferring crypto to fund a banned outfit.
Providing safe houses for terror operatives.

description: Instigating, aiding, or conspiring to commit offences using electronic communication is punishable.
examples: Running a Telegram group to plan communal violence.
Providing step-by-step guidance online to commit fraud.

description: Participation in organized groups conducting cybercrimes like phishing, ransomware, or large-scale identity theft.
examples: Operating a call center scam defrauding seniors.
Coordinating ransomware attacks on hospitals.

section_title: Public servant disobeying law with intent to cause injury
description: A public servant who knowingly disobeys legal directions intending to cause injury to any person commits an offence.
examples: An officer ignores a court order to release seized goods to harm a trader’s business.
A registrar refuses to record a lawful document to disadvantage a party.

section_title: Public servant framing incorrect record or writing
description: A public servant who frames or writes a document or record knowing it to be incorrect, to cause or knowing it likely to cause injury.
examples: Entering false land measurements to reduce someone’s plot.
Issuing a deliberately incorrect birth certificate.

section_title: Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade
description: Public servants who engage in trade or business prohibited by their position or creating conflict of interest commit an offence.
examples: A licensing officer runs a side business selling licences.
A regulator secretly owns shares in a company they oversee.

section_title: Public nuisance by obstruction or negligence
description: Causing danger, obstruction, or injury to the public by negligent or unlawful acts affecting public ways or places.
examples: Leaving construction debris blocking a public road.
Placing stalls on a footpath causing accidents.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to fire or combustible matter
description: Negligently handling fire or combustible materials endangering life or property attracts liability.
examples: Burning waste near a fuel depot causing a blaze.
Storing fireworks carelessly in a crowded market.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substances
description: Careless handling of poisonous substances endangering life or health is punishable.
examples: Improperly storing pesticides that leak into a water source.
Leaving cyanide unsecured in a lab accessible to the public.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to machinery
description: Negligently handling or maintaining machinery so as to endanger human life or safety.
examples: Running a factory machine without guards causing injuries.
Operating a crane with faulty brakes over a crowd.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to building or repair
description: Negligent building, demolition, or repair work that endangers life or property is an offence.
examples: Removing a supporting wall causing collapse risk.
Demolishing without barricades near a busy footpath.

section_title: Negligent conduct with respect to animals
description: Failing to control dangerous animals so as to endanger others is punishable.
examples: Letting an aggressive dog roam in a public park.
Riding a horse recklessly through a crowded lane.

section_title: Rash driving or riding on a public way
description: Driving or riding a vehicle rashly or negligently on a public way endangering life or safety.
examples: Speeding through a crowded market street.
Dangerous wheelies on a motorcycle amid traffic.

section_title: Public nuisance not otherwise provided for
description: Minor acts or omissions causing common injury, danger, or annoyance to the public are punishable when not specifically covered elsewhere.
examples: Blasting loud music late at night disturbing a neighborhood.
Letting sewage flow on a public street.

description: Sale, distribution, or public exhibition of obscene materials that tend to deprave or corrupt is punishable, with exceptions for public good.
examples: Selling obscene magazines to the general public.
Displaying explicit posters at a shopfront.

section_title: Sale of obscene objects to young persons
description: Selling or distributing obscene objects to persons below the prescribed age attracts higher punishment.
examples: Selling pornographic material to minors.
Providing obscene videos to schoolchildren.

section_title: Obscene acts and songs in public
description: Performing obscene acts or singing obscene songs to the annoyance of others in public places is punishable.
examples: Publicly performing explicit acts to attract attention.
Shouting vulgar songs near a school.

section_title: Injuring or defiling place of worship with intent to insult religion
description: Damaging or defiling a place of worship with intent to insult a religion or religious beliefs is an offence.
examples: Vandalizing a shrine to provoke devotees.
Smearing filth inside a prayer hall to insult a faith.

description: Voluntarily causing disturbance to any lawful religious assembly.
examples: Shouting and disrupting a prayer service.
Blasting loud music outside during a religious ceremony.

section_title: Trespassing on burial places; indignity to human corpses
description: Trespassing on burial places or deliberately insulting or outraging the dignity of human corpses is punishable.
examples: Damaging graves during a funeral.
Defiling a corpse to insult the deceased’s family.

section_title: Uttering words or acts with deliberate intent to wound religious feelings
description: Deliberately using words, signs, or visible representations intended to wound religious feelings is an offence.
examples: Publicly issuing malicious slurs against a religion to hurt followers.
Displaying a poster intended to insult religious sentiments.

section_title: Rash or negligent driving causing hurt
description: Causing hurt to any person by rash or negligent driving or riding is punishable.
examples: Knocking down a pedestrian while speeding.
Hitting a cyclist by changing lanes without checking.

section_title: Rash or negligent act endangering human life
description: Any rash or negligent act not covered elsewhere that endangers human life or personal safety is punishable.
examples: Flying kites with metal-coated strings near power lines.
Leaving manholes open without warning signs.

section_title: Causing death by rash or negligent act (non-vehicle)
description: Causing death by a rash or negligent act in contexts other than driving is punishable.
examples: Negligently handling a loaded firearm causing death.
